0.free_text: Threshold of the reaction (gamma,n+p) is 21.8 MeV.
Threshold of the reaction (gamma,n+p) is 21.8 MeV.

free_txt: The data were converted to photoneutron cross sections
by applying the measured ion-chamber response per
photon, the known number of target nuclei in the beam
and a small correction for the photon attenuation in
the sample.
A multiplicity analysis of the number of neutrons
recorded in each beam burst allows the (gamma,n) and
(gamma,2n) yields to be extracted simultaneously and
independently.
The photoproton reaction in O18 yields the product
nucleus N17, which decays by (beta-) emission with a
half-life of 4.174 sec to excited states in O17.
The O17 nucleus is left in neutron-unbound excited   l
states 95.1% of the time, and so decays predominantly
by neutron emission. The average delayed-neutron
energy was measured by using the measured ring ratios.
Some corrections were made:
- about 1% for statistical effect of pileup counts in
the detector;
- about 1% for removal of annihilation-target-out
background;
- about 2% for drift of the neutron detector and ion
chanber (beam monitor);
- about 2% for substraction of sample-blank background
- about 2% at low neutron energies to about 10% at
highest neutron energies for conversion of ring
ratios to efficiencies;
- about 6% for uncertainrty in photon-flux calibration
After the recorded neutron events were corrected for
pileup in the detector, the neutron backgrounds
(annihilation target removed) were substracted for
both the positron and electron measurements.
Because the energy spectrum of the annihilation-plus-
bremsstrahlung radiation differs from that of purely
bremsstrahlung photons, a measured correction was
applied to the ion-chamber (beam monitor) response to
normalize the electron data to the positron data.
The normalized electron data were substracted from the
positron data, leaving the neutron counts which resul
only from the annihilation radiation.
The measured sample-blank data, normalized to equal
photon flux, were substracted from the target data to
give the net target results.
After a small correction for the neutron multiplicity
in each ring, the data were corrected for the energy-
dependent efficiency of the neutron detector using
the ring-ratio result for each energy.
Resonances in the pygmy-resonance region exhibit
substantional decay branching to negative-parity
states in O17.
Significant differencies in the branching of resonance
in the giant-resonance region to the various partial
cross sections, together with the photoneutron-energy
data, allow isospin assignments to be made for all the
resonances, with the consequent delineation of the
isospin strength distribution for O18.
Evidence was found for two weak but broad resonances
above the giant-resonance region.
Neutron detector consists of a 61-cm cube of
paraffin in which 48 high-pressure BF3 tubes have been
placed.
Statistical errors only.
Positron annihilation in flight.
Upper limit for energy resolution estimated to be
about 240 keV for the 15.11 MeV resonance in 13C.
Two samples:
118.55 grams; 96.5% 18O, sample blank: 28.35 grams.
Main impurities: 16O (1.58%), 17O (1.92%)
34.7 grams; 96.6% 18O, sample blank: 19.75 grams.
Main impurities: 16O (1.6%), 17O (1.8%)

measurements of neutron multiplicities.
